column4: against defendant attorneys for violating the federal Driver's Privacy Protection Act of 1994 by obtaining
column5: disclosing
column6: and using plaintiffs' personal information from motor vehicle records for bulk solicitation without their express consent
column7: judgment of the Fourth Circuit that the use of the information satisfied the litigation exception under 18 U.S.C. section 2721(b)(4) is vacated and remanded
column8: where an attorney's solicitation of clients is not a permissible purpose covered by the (b)(4) litigation exception.

column2: Inc.
column3: 12-416| 12-416|"The Eleventh Circuit erred in affirming the dismissal of a suit brought by plaintiff Federal Trade Commission (FTC) alleging that violated section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act by unlawfully agreeing to abandon their patent challenges
column4: to refrain from launching their low-cost generic drugs
column5: and to share in the patent holder's monopoly profits
column6: where: 1) although the anti-competitive effects of the reverse settlement agreement might fall within the scope of the exclusionary potential of the patent holder's patent
column7: this does not immunize the agreement from antitrust attack; 2) the FTC should have been given the opportunity to prove its antitrust claim; but 3) reverse payment settlement agreements are not presumptively unlawful
column8: but should be reviewed by applying the ""rule of reason
column9: rather  than under a ""quick look"" approach."

column2: Inc. v. City of Los Angeles
column3: 11-798| 11-798|In a challenge to defendant's concession agreement
column4: which was implemented as part of the Clean Truck Program to govern the relationship between the defendant's Port and drayage companies whose short-haul companies move cargo into and out of the Port
column5: the Ninth Circuit's judgment finding only the driver employment provision of the agreement preempted
column6: is reversed in part and remanded
column7: where: 1) the Federal Aviation Administration Authorization Act expressly preempts the concession agreement's placard and parking requirements because defendant's placard and parking requirements relate to a motor carrier's price
column8: route
column9: or service with respect to transporting property
column10: and have the force and effect of law; but 2) this Court declines to decide in the case's present
column11: pre-enforcement posture whether Castle v. Hayes Freight Lines
column13: limits the way the Port can enforce the financial-capacity and truck-maintenance requirements upheld by the Ninth Circuit.

column1: Association for Molecular Pathology v. Myriad Genetics
column2: Inc.
column3: 12-398| 12-398|A naturally occurring DNA segment is a product of nature and not patent eligible merely because it has been isolated
column4: but cDNA
column5: whose creation results in an exons-only molecule
column6: is patent eligible because it is not naturally occurring.

column2: 12-167| 12-167|The Court of Appeals' order vacating defendant's guilty plea is vacated and remanded
column3: where: 1) under Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 11(h)
column4: vacatur of defendant's plea is not in order if the record shows no prejudice to defendant's decision to plead guilty; and 2) here
column5: though the Magistrate Judge plainly violated Rule 11(c)(1) by exhorting defendant to plead guilty
column6: the Court of Appeals failed to further consider the facts of the case
column7: and whether defendant's case should be judged under Rule 52(a)'s harmless-error standard or Rule 52(b)'s plain-error standard.

column1: Tarrant Regional Water District v. Herrmann
column2: 11-889| 11-889|The Red River Compact
column3: a congressionally sanctioned agreement that allocates water rights within the Red River basin among the States of Oklahoma
column4: Texas
column5: Arkansas
column6: and Louisiana
column7: does not pre-empt Oklahoma water statutes that restrict out-of-state diversions of water
column8: because the Compact creates no cross-border rights in its signatories for these statutes to infringe
column9: and the Oklahoma water statutes also do not run afoul of the Commerce Clause.

column2: 12-123| 12-123|In a dispute between the USDA and California raisin growers involving the failure to surrender requisite portions of raisins to the reserve as established by the California Raisin Marketing Order
column3: the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals has jurisdiction to decide petitioners' takings claim that the Order violates the Fifth Amendment's prohibition against taking property without just compensation
column4: where a federal court has jurisdiction to adjudicate a takings defense raised by a handler seeking review of a final agency order.

column2: 12-135| 12-135|In a proposed class action suit brought by a physician under contract with a health insurance company
column3: alleging nonpayment
column4: the Third Circuit's dismissal of the insurer's motion to vacate the arbitrator's decision that their contract permitted class action is affirmed where the arbitrator's decision survives the limited judicial review allowed by section 10(a)(4) of the Federal Arbitration Act.

column2: 12-62| 12-62|Sentence for bank fraud for conduct that took place in 1999 and 2000 is reversed and remanded where the Ex Post Facto Clause required that he be sentenced under the 1998 version of the Federal Sentencing Guidelines in effect at the time of his offenses rather than under the 2009 version in effect at the time of sentencing.

11-1221| 11-1221|"The Virginia State Supreme Court correctly concluded that Section D of Va. Code Ann. Section 20–111.1 is preempted by The Federal Employees' Group Life Insurance Act of 1954 (FEGLIA)
column3: where: 1) FEGLIA establishes an insurance program for federal employees
column4: permitting an employee to name a beneficiary of life insurance proceeds
column5: and specifies an ""order of precedence"" providing that an employee's death benefits accrue first to that beneficiary ahead of other potential recipients; 2) Section D of the Virginia statute provided a cause of action rendering a former spouse liable to the current spouse for the principal amount of life insurance proceeds left to them by the deceased
column6: where there has been a change in the decedent’s mari¬tal status but the deceased failed to change the designated beneficiary; and 3) Section D of the Virginia statute conflicts with the purposes and objectives of Congress."

column2: 12-694| 12-694|The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals' decision granting defendant habeas corpus relief is reversed and remanded
column3: where: 1) state supreme court reasonably concluded that evidence that the rape victim previously reported that defendant had assaulted her but the police had been unable to substantiate those allegations was properly excluded; 2) no prior decision of the U.S. Supreme Court clearly establishes that the exclusion of this evidence violated respondent's federal constitutional rights; so therefore
column4: 3) the Court of Appeals' decision to the contrary was in error.

column2: 12-207| 12-207|When officers make an arrest supported by probable cause to hold for a serious offense and bring the suspect to the station to be detained in custody
column3: taking and analyzing a cheek swab of the arrestee's DNA is
column4: like fingerprinting and photographing
column5: a legitimate police booking procedure that is reasonable under the Fourth Amendment.

column2: 12-872| 12-872|In a case raising the issue of whether the Seventh Circuit erred in holding that state and local government employees may avoid the federal Age Discrimination in Employment Act’s comprehensive remedial regime by bringing age discrimination claims directly under the Equal Protection Clause and 42 U.S.C. section 1983
column3: the writ of certiorari is dismissed as improvidently granted.

column2: 12-414| 12-414|"The Sixth Circuit erred in reversing the lower court's denial of a prisoner's habeas corpus petition
column3: challenging her second degree murder conviction on the basis of ineffective assistance of counsel during plea bargaining
column4: where the Sixth Circuit: 1) failed to apply the ""doubly deferential"" standard of review recognized by the Court's case law when it refused to credit the state court's reasonable factual finding that the prisoner's new attorney advised withdrawal of the guilty plea only after the prisoner's proclamation of innocence; and 2) assumed that counsel was ineffective where the record was silent."

column2: 12-1217| 12-1217|"In a suit under 42 U.S.C. section 1983
column3: alleging that a police officer unreasonably searched plaintiff's yard without a warrant in violation of the Fourth Amendment
column4: the Ninth Circuit's holding that the officer was not entitled to qualified immunity
column5: on grounds that the law clearly established the officer's pursuit of a suspect into plaintiff's yard did not justify his warrantless entry because the suspect was only suspected of a misdemeanor
column6: is reversed where the officer was not ""plainly incompetent"" in entering plaintiff's yard while in hot pursuit."

column1: Heimeshoff v. Hartford Life & Accident Insurance Co.
column2: 12-729| 12-729|"Dismissal of a petition for review of an ERISA plan administrator's denial of long-term disability benefits claim is affirmed
column3: where: 1) the plan required any suit to recover benefits to be filed within three years after ""proof of loss"" was due; 2) petitioner filed the petition more than three years after proof of loss was due but less than three years after the final denial; and 3) the plan's limitations provision is enforceable because absent a controlling statute to the contrary
column4: a participant and a plan may agree by contract to a particular limitations period
column5: even one that starts to run before the cause of action accrues
column6: as long as the period is reasonable."

column2: 12-609| 12-609|The Kansas Supreme Court's decision vacating defendant's murder conviction and death sentence is vacated and remanded
column3: where: 1) Buchanan v. Kentucky established that a State may introduce the results of  a court-ordered psychiatric examination for the limited purpose of rebutting a mental-status defense; 2) defendant raised a voluntary intoxication defense
column4: offering expert testimony regarding his methamphetamine use; 3) the Kansas Supreme Court erred in concluding that the Buchanan rule did not apply; and 4) the Fifth Amendment does not prohibit the government from introducing evidence from a court ordered mental evaluation of a criminal defendant to rebut that defendant's presentation of expert testimony in support of a defense of voluntary intoxication.

column2: Inc. v. Jacobs
column3: 12-815| 12-815|In a suit in which plaintiff sought a declaration that the Telecommunications Act of 1996 preempted the Iowa Utilities Board's (IUB) decision that intrastate fees applied Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) calls
column4: the Eighth Circuit's conclusion that Younger abstention was required because the ongoing state-court review concerned Iowa's important interest in regulating and enforcing state utility rates
column5: is reversed
column6: where this case does not fall within any of the three classes of exceptional cases for which Younger abstention is appropriate.

column2: 12-99| 12-99|"Writ of certiorari is dismissed as improvidently granted in an action in which the Eleventh Circuit held that: 1) certain promises made by an employer to a union are things of value; 2) an employer's promise to pay them in return for something of value from the union violates the Labor Management Relations Act if the employer intends to use the payment to ""corrupt"" the union; and 3) a union's request that an employer make such a payment violates section 302(b) of the Act if the union intends to ""extort"" the benefit  from the employer."
Inc. v. US District Court for the Western District of Texas
column3: 12-929| 12-929|"The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals' denial of a petition for a writ of mandamus requesting the district court dismiss a construction dispute case brought against petitioner
column4: or to transfer it to the Eastern District of Virginia pursuant to a forum selection clause in the parties' contract
column5: is reversed and remanded
column6: where: 1) a forum-selection clause may be enforced by a motion to transfer under 28 U.S.C. section 1404(a)
column7: which provides that ""[f]or the convenience of parties and witnesses
column8: in the interest of justice
column9: a district court may transfer any civil action to any other district or division where it might have been brought or to any district or division to which all parties have consented;"" 2) when a defendant files a section 1404(a) motion
column10: a district court should transfer the case unless extraordinary circumstances unrelated to the convenience of the parties clearly disfavor a transfer; and 3) no such exceptional factors appear to be present in this case."

column2: 12-562| 12-562|The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeal's affirmation of the district court's holding that defendants' partnerships were properly disregarded as shams but that the valuation-misstatement penalty did not apply
column3: is reversed
column4: where: 1) the district court had jurisdiction to determine whether the partnerships' lack of economic substance could justify imposing a  valuation-misstatement penalty on the partners; and 2) the penalty is applicable to tax underpayments resulting from the defendant-partners' participation in the COBRA tax shelter.

column2: 13-113| 13-113|In a suit to recover interest from the government on plaintiff's tax overpayment for the period between the payment and the ultimate refund

column4: and the date of overpayment was the date that plaintiff requested that the IRS treat the remittances as payments of tax

column6: where: 1) the government now argues that the only basis for jurisdiction
column7: and the only general waiver of sovereign immunity that encompasses plaintiff's claim

column9: 28 U.S.C. section 1491(a); and 2) the Sixth Circuit should have the first opportunity to consider the government's new contention with respect to jurisdiction in this case.
